term.name: cooperative ITS
term.definition: subset of ITS ( REF id95C4A86465B74046823106670EF95C77 ) where information is shared among physical objects based on mutual security agreements with a credentialing system

term.name: intelligent transport system
term.definition: technology system ( REF id03252B24F74349ac87D95187F13128C7 ) that is designed to benefit a surface transport system ( REF id261629D58D7B439b8DAE5905D2EEF4D5 )
term.note: Benefits potentially include, but are not limited to, increased safety, sustainability, efficiency, and comfort.

The long form (i.e., "intelligent transport system") is often used when the noun is used as a subject, whereas the abbreviation (i.e., “ITS”) is often used to modify another noun (e.g., “Intelligent transport systems provide ITS services.”).

There is not complete agreement on the precise limits of ITS. Currently, the term is almost exclusively applied to ground-based travel of goods and people over significant distances. The term is viewed as including ferry systems, which often form an integ

term.name: surface transport system
term.definition: transport system ( REF id8648D088383A40a19D19B3E02A7060DF ) designed to move physical entities across the surface of the earth Note 1 to entry: A surface transport system might include tunnels, bridges, and similar elements.

term.name: system
term.definition: combination of interacting elements organized to achieve one or more stated purposes

term.name: technology system
term.definition: system that is comprised of information, communication, sensor, and control technologies

term.name: transport system
term.definition: system of infrastructure elements and optionally vehicles that jointly are designed to move entities from an origin to a destination Note 1 to entry: Transport systems are not necessarily limited to the transport of physical entities; the Internet could be considered a transport system of electronic entities.

term.name: consumer
term.definition: entity that has a need to be fulfilled

term.name: entity
term.definition: concrete or abstract thing that exists, did exist, or might exist, including associations among these things EXAMPLE: A person, object, event, idea, process, etc. [Source: ISO/TR 17185-1]

term.name: need
term.definition: factor or condition necessary to achieved desired results within a specified context of use [Adapted from ISO 25060:2010(en), 2.25]

term.name: service
term.definition: performance of one or more tasks or provision of one or more facilities to enable one or more tasks for a consumer to fulfil a need

term.name: service provider
term.definition: entity that delivers one or more services

term.name: service
term.definition: <ITS> performance of one or more tasks that fulfils an ITS user need for an ITS user

term.name: service provider
term.definition: <ITS> entity that delivers one or more ITS services

term.name: user
term.definition: <ITS> entity that has an ITS user need to be fulfilled

term.name: user need
term.definition: <ITS> need of an entity external to the intelligent transport system for a surface transport system benefit that can be met with the use of a technology system

term.name: bounded, secured, managed domain
term.definition: controlled processing environment that adheres to a minimum set of management and security principles and procedures so as to establish a level of trust between itself and other similar ITS stations with which it might communicate

term.name: service
term.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks that fulfils an ITS-S user need for an ITS-S user

term.name: service provider
term.definition: <ITS-S> ITS-S that delivers one or more ITS-S services

term.name: user
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity that has an ITS-S user need

term.name: user need
term.definition: <ITS-S> need for processing within a bounded, secure, managed domain

term.name: communication need
term.definition: <ITS-S> need for communication functionality that connects an ITS-S to other nodes

term.name: communication process
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity that delivers one or more ITS-S communication services

term.name: communication service
term.definition: <ITS-S> performance of one or more tasks that fulfils an ITS-S communication need for an ITS-S communication user

term.name: communication user
term.definition: <ITS-S> entity that has an ITS-S communication need

term.name: interoperability design
term.definition: characteristics necessary to fully define how various system elements and terminators interoperate to provide a service Note 1 to entry: Characteristics often include but are not limited to functional, performance, and interface requirements.

term.name: ITS application
term.definition: interoperability design for an ITS service

term.name: ITS application specification
term.definition: one or more documents that detail all necessary requirements for an ITS application

term.name: ITS deployment
term.definition: installation capable of implementing one or more ITS applications Note 1 to entry: An ITS deployment typically refers to the support, central and roadside ITS stations coupled with a tacit acknowledgement of the mobile ITS stations that will communicate with the support, central, or roadside ITS stations.

term.name: ITS implementation
term.definition: integration of each system element and terminator necessary to implement one or more ITS applications Note 1 to entry: An ITS application typically requires multiple components (e.g., a ITS-S acting as a user and another ITS-S acting as a provider). An ITS implementation includes a sample of each component necessary for the service but often does not represent a complete deployment. Note 2 to entry: An ITS implementation is typically used for a laboratory or other experimental environment prior to a full-scale deployment.

term.name: ITS-S application process
term.definition: element in an ITS station that performs information processing for an ITS-S service EDITOR’S NOTE 1: It is unclear if this term is intended to describe the 1) the logical concept of a process that fulfils a role (e.g., "word processor"), 2) a specific implementation of the logical concept (e.g., "MS Word"), 3) a specific deployment of that implementation (e.g., "MS Word with license XXX"), or a specific run-time instance of the implementation. I believe our standards will need to be clear about these distinctions, especially as we get into security, provisioning, and deployment issues.

term.name: ITS-S application process implementation
term.definition: implementation of an ITS-S application process Note 1 to entry: A unique implementation is typically associated with an implementation name, a version, and release number.

term.name: ITS-S application process installation
term.definition: installation of an ITS-S application process implementation Note 1 to entry: A unique installation is typically associated with a specific license code or serial number.

term.name: ITS-S application process instance
term.definition: run-time instance of an ITS-S application process installation

term.name: architecture
term.definition: <system> fundamental concepts or properties of a system in its environment embodied in its elements, relationships, and in the principles of its design and evolution [ISO 42010:2011, 3.2]

term.name: architecture description
term.definition: work product used to express an architecture [ISO 42010:2011, 3.3]

term.name: architecture framework
term.definition: conventions, principles and practices for the description of architectures established within a specific domain of application and/or community of stakeholders EXAMPLE 1 Generalised Enterprise Reference Architecture and Methodologies (GERAM) [ISO 15704] is an architecture framework. EXAMPLE 2 Reference Model of Open Distributed Processing (RM-ODP) [ISO/IEC 10746] is an architecture framework. [ISO 42010:2011, 3.4]

term.name: architecture model
term.definition: work product representing one or more architecture views and expressed in a format governed by a model kind

term.name: architecture view
term.definition: work product expressing the architecture of a system from the perspective of specific system concerns [ISO 42010:2011, 3.5]

term.name: architecture viewpoint
term.definition: work product establishing the conventions for the construction, interpretation and use of architecture views to frame specific system concerns [ISO 42010:2011, 3.6]

term.name: concern
term.definition: <system> interest in a system relevant to one or more of its stakeholders NOTE A concern pertains to any influence on a system in its environment, including developmental, technological, business, operational, organizational, political, economic, legal, regulatory, ecological and social influences. [ISO 42010:2011, 3.7]

term.name: element
term.definition: <system> component member of an architecture

term.name: environment
term.definition: <system> <font color="#313131">context determining the setting and circumstances of all influences upon a system</font> <font color="#313131">[ISO/IEC/IEEE 42010:2011, 3.8]</font>

term.name: model kind
term.definition: conventions for a type of modelling NOTE Examples of model kinds include data flow diagrams, class diagrams, Petri nets, balance sheets, organization charts and state transition models. [ISO 42010:2011, 3.9]

term.name: stakeholder
term.definition: <system> individual, team, organization, or classes thereof, having an interest in a system [ISO 42010:2011, 3.10]

term.name: C-ITS architecture
term.definition: architecture for one or more ITS services where each service requires at least one C-ITS data exchange

term.name: deployment architecture
term.definition: architecture that provides a vision of a specific deployment of a system

term.name: ITS architecture
term.definition: architecture for one or more ITS services Note 1 to entry: An ITS architecture might be a reference, planning, or deployment architecture. Note 2 to entry: The Harmonised Architecture Reference for Technical Standards (HARTS; http://htg7.org) is an example of an ITS reference architecture.

term.name: ITS-S architecture
term.definition: reference architecture for ITS components as defined in ISO 21217 Note 1 to entry: The ITS-S architecture is the preferred architecture for ITS components.

term.name: planning architecture
term.definition: architecture that provides a long-term vision of system elements that may be deployed and managed by different projects and/or entities Note 1 to entry: Some countries use the term "regional architecture", but in international standards, the term "regional" is avoided due to its multiple meanings.

term.name: reference architecture
term.definition: template solution for an architecture for a particular domain<sup> [14]</sup> Note 1 to entry: Interface standards are based on a reference architecture, which should be explicitly described.

term.name: communications view
term.definition: <font color="#1a1a1a">architecture view </font>from the communications viewpoint

term.name: communications viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint used to frame communication interface concerns, including all layers of the OSI stack and related management and security issues

term.name: functional view
term.definition: <font color="#1a1a1a">architecture view </font>from the functional viewpoint

term.name: functional viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint used to frame the functionality concerns, including the definition of processes that perform transport functions and data flows shared between these processes

term.name: physical view
term.definition: <font color="#1a1a1a">architecture view </font>from the physical viewpoint Note 1 to entry: The term "deployment view" is sometimes used within the broader ICT community, but the term "physical view" is preferred to prevent confusion between the physical view of a reference architecture and any part of a deployment architecture.

term.name: physical viewpoint
term.definition: architecture viewpoint used to frame system engineering concerns, including the assignment of functionality to physical objects and the interfaces among these physical objects

package.name: 3.4.4 Physical view of an ITS architecture

term.name: functional object
term.definition: group of similar system processes from the functional view of the architecture that are jointly assigned to an ITS component in the physical view.

term.name: information flow
term.definition: information that is exchanged between physical objects

term.name: information triple
term.definition: information flow from a physical object acting as an information source and sent to another physical object acting as an information sink

term.name: ITS component
term.definition: physical object that has been assigned one or more ITS functional objects Note 1 to entry: Physical objects are ITS components if they are an integral part of the system; otherwise they are terminators.

term.name: physical object
term.definition: element within the physical view of an ITS architecture that represents an physical entity that interacts with other physical objects in the provision of ITS services

term.name: terminator
term.definition: physical object that represents an external user of ITS

term.name: ITS station
term.definition: ITS component that provides a bounded secured managed domain and conforms to the ITS station architecture Note 1 to entry: The ITS station architecture is defined in ISO 21217. EDITOR’S NOTE 1 There appears to be ambiguity (and perhaps disagreement within the industry) as to whether a "bounded secured managed domain" is the logical domain within each ITS-S or if it represents the ITS-S network. The proposed definition uses the former concept. EDITOR’S NOTE 2 The proposed definition assumes that an ITS-S does not cease being an ITS-S simply because it is disconnected from any network; therefore "in a communications network" is an invalid constraint. EDITOR’S NOTE 3 As can be seen in a few examples, the phrase "network, comprised of applications…" is ambiguous as it is unclear if the ITS-S is comprised of the items or if the network is comprised of the items. EDITOR’S NOTE 4 The proposed definition assumes that ITS-S are not required to have a wireless network interface. It is my understanding that any ITS device that conformed to the ITS-S architecture (which is almost a null requirement) and provides a BSMD (which is ill-defined) would be considered an ITS-S. Thus, at least at present, I see the term ITS-S to really mean any ITS physical entity that can claim to be secure (and it would be just a claim since there are no measurable requirements). And in fact, some definitions even make the BSMD optional – though I think this is wildly unwise. EDITOR’S NOTE 5 Logically, an ITS-S seldom (if ever) provides ITS services because an ITS-S is a component of an ITS network; the ITS service is provided by the ITS as a whole. The ITS-S logically should provide ITS-S services, or more specifically, the ITS-S is comprised of the ITS-S architectural components (i.e., applications entity, facilities layer, etc), which all provide ITS-S services.

package.name: 3.4.6 Functional view of an ITS architecture

term.name: data flow
term.definition: <font color="#1a1a1a">Representation of data flowing between processes or between a process and a terminator</font>

term.name: process
term.definition: function or activity defined in the functional view

term.name: process specification
term.definition: <font color="#1a1a1a">textual definition of a lowest-level process</font>

term.name: data concept
term.definition: item that may be stored in a data dictionary that refers to an abstraction or thing in the natural world that can be identified with explicit boundaries and meaning and whose properties and behaviour all follow the same rules Note 1 to entry: Data concepts can be classified into the following types: object class, value domain, data element, aggregate domain, data frame, message, interface dialogue, dictionary document, or module [ISO 14817-1]

term.name: data concept registry
term.definition: <font color="#313131">electronic data dictionary that follows precise documented rules for the registration and management of stored data concepts; it typically also includes advanced features for adding, retrieving, and working with its contents</font> <font color="#313131">Note 1 to entry: The data concept registry contains meta-attributes about data concepts in terms of their names and representational forms as well as the semantics associated with the data concepts. A data concept registry may contain data that assists information interchange and re-use, both from the perspective of human users and for machine-interpretation of data concepts.</font>

term.name: data dictionary
term.definition: <font color="#313131">listing of data concepts and their meta-attributes in a consistent format</font>

term.name: meta-attribute
term.definition: <font color="#313131">documenting characteristic of a data concept that is stored in a data dictionary</font>

term.name: aggregate domain
term.definition: data concept that defines a grouping of data elements and/or data frames

term.name: data element
term.definition: data concept represented by a specific value domain and that describes a single atomic property about an object class. Note 1 to entry: A data element is composed of an object class, a property of the represented object class and a value domain.

term.name: data frame
term.definition: data concept represented by a specific aggregate domain and that describes information of interest through a useful grouping of more atomic properties about one or more object classes. Note 1 to entry: The grouping may be a set, sequence, or a choice.

term.name: interface dialogue
term.definition: data concept that defines bi-directional communication sequence between two parties in accordance with predetermined protocols

term.name: message
term.definition: data concept that is a grouping of data elements, data frames, or data elements and data frames that is used to convey a complete set of information

term.name: object class
term.definition: description of a set of objects that share the same properties, relationships, and semantics Note 1 to entry: Adapted from ISO/IEC 11179-1:2013; an object class is conceptually similar to an ISO/IEC 11179 object, but it does not include operations or methods and ISO/IEC 11179 "attributes" are called "properties" in this International Standard.

term.name: value domain
term.definition: data concept that defines a set of permissible values

term.name: area location
term.definition: location that has a two-dimensional character

term.name: dynamic location reference
term.definition: location reference generated on-the-fly based on geographic properties in a digital map database [ISO 17572-1:2015(en), 2.1.11]

term.name: linear location
term.definition: <font color="#313131">location that has a one-dimensional character</font> <font color="#042655">ISO 17572-1:2015(en), 2.1.19</font>

term.name: link location
term.definition: <font color="#313131">location identifiable by a part of the road network database having one identifier or having a uniquely identifiable combination of attributes throughout the continuous stretch</font> <font color="#042655">ISO 17572-1:2015(en), 2.1.22</font>

term.name: location
term.definition: <font color="#313131">position on the surface of the earth</font>

term.name: location code
term.definition: <font color="#042655">identifier assigned to a location reference</font> <font color="#042655">Note 1 to entry: A location code is often a numeric or alphanumeric identifier, but could be a textual name, symbol, or any other type of identifier.</font>

term.name: location reference
term.definition: <font color="#042655">specification of a location </font><font color="#313131">according to a specific set of rules</font>

term.name: location referencing
term.definition: <font color="#313131">method for referencing locations to facilitate the exchange of location related information between different systems</font> <font color="#042655">ISO/TS 18234-4:2006(en), 3.4</font>

term.name: location table
term.definition: table of one or more entries that unambiguously defines a location according to a known set of conventions

term.name: point location
term.definition: <font color="#313131">location that has a zero-dimensional character</font> <font color="#042655">ISO 17572-1:2015(en), 2.1.33</font>

term.name: pre-coded location reference
term.definition: <font color="#313131">location reference using a unique identifier that is agreed upon in both sender and receiver system to select a location from a set of pre-coded locations</font> <font color="#042655">ISO 17572-1:2015(en), 2.1.35</font>

term.name: carriageway
term.definition: syn: roadway part of road link designed for use by motor vehicles

term.name: dual carriageway
term.definition: syn: divided highway roadway comprised of exactly two carriageways Note 1 to entry: The two carriageways are typically designed for travel in opposite directions.

term.name: lane
term.definition:
strip of roadway intended for a specific purpose along its length with adequate clearance for its purpose
Note 1 to entry: Lanes are often bounded by lane markings. Note 2 to entry: Lanes may be significantly wider than the normal vehicle width to allow variance in lane position of the vehicle as well as for various vehicle dimensions. Note 3 to entry: The term "lane" is often used in place of "travel lane" but other lane types exist. EXAMPLE shoulder

term.name: lay-by
term.definition:
short lane at the edge of a carriageway designed to allow a motor vehicle to temporarily stop while traffic in other lanes proceed
Note 1 to entry: Lay-bys might be used for emergency situations, picking up/dropping off passengers, etc.

term.name: multi-carriageway
term.definition: roadway comprised of more than two carriageways Note 1 to entry: The separate carriageways are typically designed for separate traffic for (often multiple) specific operational reasons, such as direction of travel, category of vehicle (e.g., high occupancy vehicle), local versus through travel, etc.

term.name: reserved lane
term.definition:
travel lane restricted to a specific subset of motor vehicles
EXAMPLE 1 Bus lane EXAMPLE 2 High-occupancy vehicle lane

term.name: right-of-way
term.definition: easement of land reserved for transportation purposes Note 1 to entry: The right-of-way includes all carriageways as well as a significant width to allow for roadside devices, clearance zones, sidewalks, drainage facilities, sound walls, etc.

term.name: road
term.definition:
contiguous curvilinear length of the road network that shares the same name
Note 1 to entry: A road may turn at a junction.
Note 2 to entry: A length of the road network may be referenced by multiple names (e.g., Main Street and Route 7). In this case, there would be two "roads" that share the same set of "carriageways".

term.name: roadside
term.definition: width between one edge of the right-of-way and the closest edge of a carriageway

term.name: roadway
term.definition: part of the right-of-way designed for use by motor vehicles Note 1 to entry: Roadway relates to a cross-section of a road facility (i.e., zero length). See "road", "road section", "road segment", and "road link" for different types of stretches of roadway.

term.name: separation barrier
term.definition: barrier that separates carriageways

term.name: shoulder
term.definition: lane between the edge of a carriageway and any slope or edge of right-of-way. Note 1 to entry: The shoulder might be used for emergency stops or other purposes in addition to providing a clear zone and to promote ground stability at the edge of the carriageway.

term.name: single carriageway
term.definition: syn: undivided highway roadway comprised of exactly one carriageway

term.name: travel lane
term.definition: lane intended to allow motor vehicles to travel from one end of a road link to the other

term.name: traveled way
term.definition: collection of all travel lanes of a carriageway

term.name: directional lanes
term.definition: collection of all travel lanes of a road link that are intended to allow travel in the same direction Note 1 to entry: In actual use, an indication of the direction typically replaces the term "directional" EXAMPLE 1 The eastbound lanes on a road EXAMPLE 2 The north approach lanes at an intersection

term.name: directional lanes link
term.definition: collection of all lane links of the same road link designed for travel in the same direction

term.name: lane link
term.definition: lane with starting and ending points that correspond to the starting and ending points of a road link

term.name: lane section
term.definition: complete sequential series of lane segments within a road section

term.name: lane segment
term.definition: complete sequential series of lane links within a road segment Note 1 to entry: A lane segment might start or end at locations other than the start or end of the corresponding road segment (e.g., a lane may start mid-block).

term.name: road link
term.definition:
contiguous length of a road segment that is described by the same set of physical characteristics
Note 1 to entry: The definition of road segments is highly dependent on what characteristics are modelled by the implementation. Characteristics that might result in a new road segment include: addition or subtraction of a lane, a change in roadway width, the change of road type (e.g., start/end of a bridge), etc.

term.name: road network
term.definition: network of routes designed for the use of motor vehicles

term.name: road section
term.definition:
contiguous length of a road that shares the same management and operational characteristics
EXAMPLE A traffic signal timing plan is applied to one road section.

term.name: road segment
term.definition: contiguous length of a road section bounded by a junction or a termination point at both ends

term.name: approach lane
term.definition: travel lane designed for entry into a junction

term.name: approach link
term.definition: directional lanes link representing all approach lanes on a road link

term.name: egress lane
term.definition: travel lane designed for exiting from a junction

term.name: egress link
term.definition: directional lanes link representing all egress lanes on a road link

term.name: interchange
term.definition: junction where at least one movement is grade separated from all other movements Note 1 to entry: The grade separation allows travelers on the link to pass unimpeded through the junction when congestion is not present. Note 2 to entry: The concept of an interchange includes all movements at the junction, which may include multiple intersections. Example: A diamond interchange has two intersections.

term.name: intersection
term.definition: at-grade junction

term.name: junction
term.definition:
nexus where two or more carriageways meet and travelers may connect to adjoining links
Note 1 to entry: While the nexus is sometimes modelled as a point, it does in fact consume space

term.name: maneuver
term.definition: movement from an approach lane to an egress lane

term.name: articulated vehicle
term.definition: "Articulated vehicle" means a vehicle which consists of two or more rigid sections which articulate relative to one another; the passenger compartments of each section intercommunicate so that passengers can move freely between them; the rigid sections are permanently connected so that they can only be separated by an operation involving facilities which are normally only found in a workshop; [UNECE WP.29/1045]

term.name: bicycle
term.definition: human-powered vehicle with two wheels

term.name: cart
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle propelled by an animal (which might be a person)

term.name: commercial vehicle
term.definition: <font color="#313131">any type of motor vehicle used for transporting goods or paid passengers</font> <font color="#042655">ISO/TR 19083-1:2016(en), 3.5</font>

term.name: commerical motor vehicle
term.definition:
self-propelled or towed motor vehicle (3.50) used on a highway in interstate commerce to transport passengers or property when the vehicle
  • a) has a gross vehicle weight rating or gross combination weight rating, or gross vehicle weight or gross combination weight, of 4 536 kg (10 001 pounds) or more, whichever is greater,
  • b) is designed or used to transport more than 8 passengers (including the driver) for compensation,
  • c) is designed or used to transport more than 15 passengers, including the driver, and is not used to transport passengers for compensation, or
  • d) is used in transporting material found by the Secretary of Transportation to be hazardous under 49 USC 5103 and transported in a quantity requiring placarding under regulations prescribed by the Secretary under 49 CFR, subtitle B, chapter I, subchapter C
ISO/TS 19091:2017(en), 3.6

term.name: connected vehicle
term.definition: vehicle that contains a connected device (3.8) ISO/TS 19091:2017(en), 3.9 equipped vehicle(s) vehicles equipped with the device(s) that provide the role of an ITS-station in the C-ITS (3.6) context ISO/TR 17427-3:2015(en), 3.14

term.name: electric vehicle
term.definition: <font color="#313131">vehicle that is (partly) electrically powered and operated</font> <font color="#042655">ISO/TS 21219-25:2017(en), 3.1</font>

term.name: external in-vehicle device
term.definition: <font color="#313131">devices such as mobile phones or dedicated units consisting of GNSS and/or cellular modules that are connected to DSRC-OBE for upgrading the functionalities of it</font> <font color="#042655">ISO/TS 16785:2014(en), 3.8</font>

term.name: externally-propelled vehicle
term.definition: vehicle propelled by an external entity Note 1 to entry: The external entity is often a self-propelled vehicle, but may be any external source, including and not limited to an animal (e.g., an ox pulling a cart), a cable (e.g., San Francisco Trolley cars), or magnets (e.g., a maglev train).

term.name: goods vehicle
term.definition: motor vehicle with four or more wheels designed primarily for the carriage of goods per UNECE WP.29/1045 Note 1 to entry: UNECE WP.29/1045 provides a formula to disambiguate between passenger vehicles (Category 1 vehicles) and goods vehicles (Category 2 vehicles).

term.name: heavy vehicle
term.definition: <font color="#313131">any single vehicle or combination of vehicles defined as Category 1-2 or Category 2 in the United Nations Economic and Social Council World Forum for Harmonization of Vehicle Regulations (WP.29) TRANS/WP.29/1045</font> <font color="#042655">ISO 19237:2017(en), 3.4</font>

term.name: human-powered vehicle
term.definition: vehicle propelled by the muscular energy of one or more on-board person(s)

term.name: light-duty passenger vehicle
term.definition: passenger vehicle with not more than eight seating positions in addition to the driver’s seating position (if any) and not designed for standing passengers

term.name: maglev vehicle
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle that is levitated through the use of opposing magnets and propelled through the use of coordinated electro-magnets along a track

term.name: moped
term.definition: motor vehicle with 2 or 3 wheels and a maximum design speed not exceeding 50 km/h

term.name: motor vehicle
term.definition: vehicle propelled by an on-board motor, having at least two wheels, and designed to be used on a road network

term.name: motorcycle
term.definition: motor vehicle with 2 or 3 wheels and a maximum design speed exceeding 50 km/h

term.name: passenger shuttle
term.definition: passenger vehicle designed for the carriage of more than eight passengers, whether seated or standing, in addition to the driver (if any)

term.name: passenger vehicle
term.definition: motor vehicle with four or more wheels designed primarily for the carriage of (a) person(s)

term.name: public transport vehicle
term.definition: vehicle (3.50) specifically designed to carry multiple passengers such as a bus ISO/TS 19091:2017(en), 3.35

term.name: regulated commercial freight vehicle
term.definition: vehicle that is subject to regulations determined by the jurisdiction (4.28) as to its use on the road system of the jurisdiction in regulated circumstances, subject to certain conditions, and in compliance with specific regulations for that class of regulated vehicle ISO 15638-21:2018(en), 3.35

term.name: self-propelled vehicle
term.definition: vehicle propelled by an on-board source Note 1 to entry: Contrast to externally propelled vehicle.

term.name: sidecar
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle attached to a motorcycle

term.name: trailer
term.definition: externally-propelled vehicle pulled by another vehicle EDITOR’S NOTE: Should this include self-propelled vehicles being towed?

term.name: vehicle
term.definition: <font color="#042655">entity used to transport people or physical goods</font>

term.name: scenario
term.definition: <use case> a description of the sequence of events from the user’s perspective to perform a task in a specified context [ISO/IEC 25062:2006(en), A.17]

term.name: use case
term.definition: description of the behavioural requirements of a system and its interaction with a user [ISO/IEC/IEEE 26515:2011(en), 4.15]
